entry.title: enable barcode for Serial ID on RF screen
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

We have a requirement to enable Barcode for Serial ID field in Bin-to-Bin scenario. Upon scanning the barcode string, Serial ID need be decoded so that it gets added as new line item to the scanned List.

This way business will get to know how many serial Ids are scanned.

 FM - /SCWM/RF_XSERNR_PAI gets triggered when you enter Serial Id manually or when 2D barcode string is entered in Input field.

It is working when we enter Serial ID manually hit enter.  Serial ID gets add to the scanned list as below.

In the standard RF screen, Serial ID field is just declared of type Input/Output. We have created custom screen and enabled property Barcode = 'TRUE' and checked it as scrollable. default length made it as 255, output as 18.

As we declared output length as 18 and we are passing input as 2D barcode string, ABAP dump is raised with message ‘Output field too short for converted value’ because of the SERIAL ID conversion exit routine.

Dump says System is expecting plain Serial ID as an input. We validated BADI - /SCWM/EX_BARC_DECODE but it is not triggering in our case.

FYI - Conversion routine is triggered before PAI FM is triggered.

Expectation – We are looking for BADI or Enhancement before Routine where we can write custom logic to decode the barcode string and pass Serial Id as input (like we are currently entering manually).

I just wanted to check if anyone has worked on similar kind of requirement.

RF menu Path - 050205, Logical transaction -AHPRTO, step - XSERNR

 

Thank you.

Regards,

Karthik

entry.title: Issue with Visibility of Domestic Non-Deductible Tax Code in Down Payment Request in SAP ByDesign
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I’ve encountered an issue in SAP Business ByDesign related to tax codes on Supplier’s down payment requests.

Here’s the scenario:

  •  In the Supplier Invoicing work center, while creating a Down Payment Request, I do not see the tax code “Domestic Purchase Standard Rate – Not Deductible” as an option.
  • When I create a new invoice, I can see this tax code and select it without any issues.
  • However, when I try to create a down payment request, I do not see the “Domestic Purchase Standard Rate Not Deductible” tax code as an option. Instead, I only see the “Domestic purchase Standard Rate Fully Deductible” option.

I’ve already gone into the Business Configuration under Fine-Tuning and defined  a new tax code as “Not Deductible.” But whenever I change the tax type to “Not Deductible,” the tax code does not appear in the down payment request. If I switch it back to “Fully Deductible,” it shows up again.

Is there a workaround or a configuration step I might have missed that would allow this tax code to be available for down payment requests?

Thank you in advance for your help!

Best regards,

entry.title: Why is Automatic Picking Not Triggered for Return Deliveries in S/4HANA Cloud?
entry.content:
We observed that automatic picking is not being triggered for return deliveries in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Even though the "Automatic Picking" checkbox is enabled for the shipping point, the picked quantity remains zero upon return delivery creation.

We've confirmed that:
- The return delivery type (e.g., LR2) is used.
- The item category (e.g., RENV) is relevant for picking.
- Shipping point config has "Automatic Picking" enabled.
- This is a non-WM scenario.
  
Is this standard system behavior, and if so, what is the recommended approach for streamlining picking in return deliveries?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Why is Automatic Picking Not Triggered for Return Del...
entry.content:
This is standard system behavior.

As per current SAP S/4HANA Cloud functionality, the "Automatic Picking" checkbox in the shipping point configuration only applies to outbound delivery scenarios.

**Return Deliveries** are treated as inbound processes in the system logic, even when using outbound delivery types such as LR2. Therefore, automatic picking is **not triggered**.

**Workaround:**  
If you would like to bypass manual picking for return deliveries, you can uncheck the **“Relevant for Picking”** flag for the return delivery item category (e.g., RENV) via:

`SSCUI 102974 – Define Delivery Item Categories`

Once this flag is disabled, the system no longer expects picking quantities to be maintained, and you can post goods movement directly.

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Inventory Count - Posting only possible in periods 20...
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P 

You've encountered a common issue with physical inventory postings at the start of a new month. The problem isn't that you can't post to August, but that the physical inventory document itself is linked to the current month's posting period.

Here's why you're encountering those errors and how to resolve them.

The Problem

When you created the physical inventory document today, September 1st, SAP kindly assigned it to the current open posting period, which is September 2025.

Although your count was in August, the system requires subsequent postings for that document to be dated within its creation period. It prevents backdating for documents created in the new period.

Message M7734 is a standard physical inventory notification. It indicates that after a physical inventory document is created for a specific period, such as September 2025, any subsequent difference postings related to that document must be made within the same period or a later one.

Message M7053 is a general period-end closing notification indicating which periods are open for posting. It shows that both August and September were open, but the process stopped due to the first error.

The main issue is that the physical inventory document acts as a transactional record with a life cycle tied to its creation period. Although the physical count occurred in August, the entry into SAP happened in September, and the system requires a consistent process.

The Solution

The straightforward solution is to change the posting date to September.

You must post the inventory differences with a posting date within the current period (e.g., September 1, 2025). The system will accurately record the differences from your August count. The discrepancy in dates between your physical count and the posting is a standard part of the business process.

You will not be able to post the differences for this document with an August date. You would have had to create the physical inventory document itself on or before August 31st to be able to post the differences in that month.

I hope this helps you get the differences posted without any further errors.

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: How to use SAP hana-client module with Vite / SvelteKit?
entry.content:
Hi all,

I've been trying to use @SAP/hana-client module on a SvelteKit project (which bundles everything using Vite). With default configs, it runs fine on dev mode (no SSR/prerendering). However, when trying to build the app, it throws an exception trying to prerender the binary blobs, which is expected. When instructing Vite not to prerender the lib, there are errors on the import, as it is a CommonJS module and was not "ESM-ized" by Vite build process. We then need to import it as "import * as hana from (...)" instead of "import hana from (...)", as it says the module doesn't have a default export, which makes the app finally build, but then breaks the dev mode, because createPool() is now undiscoverable in ESM mode. Also, dev mode only runs if the "ssr" config (see below) is not used, or else it gives an error trying to use require(), which is not defined on ESM mode.

Is there a way users are supposed to handle the combination of CommonJS + binary blobs? Are there plans of migrating the lib to standard ESM?

The Vite configs (vite.config.ts) used to ignore the module on prerendering are:

  ssr: {
    noExternal: ["@sap/hana-client"],
  },
  optimizeDeps: {
    exclude: ['@sap/hana-client']  // don't try to pre-bundle it
  },
  build: {
    rollupOptions: {
      plugins: [
        commonjs({
          ignoreDynamicRequires: true
        })
      ]
    }
  },

 Thanks in advance,
Lawisch

entry.title: Re: sapgui front end that compatible for EHP4 and EHP 8
entry.content:
Please read this very important information on Sapgui For Windows 8.00 

3218166 - SAP GUI for Windows: Functional differences of the 64bit version compared to the 32bit version 

Specific restrictions of the 64bit version

  • No support for systems older than SAP_BASIS 7.00

    The 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows does not support SAP systems running with older versions than SAP_BASIS 7.00. Even though all of these SAP products are already out of support by SAP this may still affect you. If you need to use legacy systems, keep using the 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows.
    When trying to log on to such a legacy system, the user will see a popup with additional information and the logon attempt will be refused.

  • Usage of saprotwr.dll (Running Objects Table Wrapper - see also documentation at https://help.sap.com/docs/sap_gui_for_windows/b47d018c3b9b45e897faf66a6c0885a8/3c48aec0416442eaa8667bd95a1cd8c8.html?locale=en-US)

    Some components / products make use of the library saprotwr.dll to access SAP GUI Scripting via COM. Since saprotwr.dll naturally is a 64bit file when installed with a 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows, only 64bit processes can access this. This is because there is no way for a 32bit process to use a 64bit COM component even though there is a way for 64bit processes to use 32bit COM components ("DllSurrogate"). Therefore, if you are using saprotwr.dll in your component / product, you need to make sure that the process from which this is called can be a 64bit process if the 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows is used. Else the attempt to invoke saprotwr.dll will fail.

  • Support for hospital graphic (gnhox.exe)

    The hospital graphic can only be used in very old SAP systems and there are technical alternatives. Therefore, this component is not included in the installation of a 64bit version of SAP GUI for Windows. See SAP Note 3083686.

  • No support for 32bit versions of automation components

    The installation of a 64bit version of SAP GUI contains the automation components from SAP Note 2724656 (Logon Control, Table Control, Function Control and BAPI Control) only as 64bit versions. You cannot call these 64bit objects from 32bit processes like Microsoft Excel. If you need to use these components from 32bit processes, you need to keep using the 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows. This is one of the reasons why we generally recommend to take into account the features / bitness of other programs integrating with SAP GUI when deciding for a 64bit or 32bit version of SAP GUI for Windows.

Cost-Benefit Analysis:
While you're paying for embedded SAC as part of S/4HANA Cloud, the operational benefits and reduced complexity of using standalone SAC far outweigh the unused embedded license cost. The single-tenant approach with full functionality will provide better ROI through:

  • Reduced development time
  • Lower maintenance overhead
  • Superior end-user experience
  • Scalable architecture for future requirements

Bottom line: Use standalone SAC as part of BDC and treat embedded SAC as a sunk cost. The architectural simplicity and feature completeness make this the clear choice for your multi-source operational reporting requirements.

Hope this helps.

Best,
James

entry.title: Re: enable barcode for Serial ID on RF screen
entry.content:
Hi Karthik,

If a barcode needs to be decoded, it is usually generated based on certain standard, like GS1 Standard. If you are in this case, the good news is that SAP supports the GS1 on EWM RFUI for Product ID, Batch, SSCC HU, SN... You may check note 3364010 - FAQ: EWM RF transactions using SAP GUI for HTML. 

If you are using EWM Private Cloud, you may check the setting on Extended Warehouse Management->Mobile Data Entry->Maintain Bar Code Specification, to double check and adjust your barcode information here to match the bar code on the label. You metioned the BAdI was not triggered, you may check if the barcode has been assigned to your warehouse in this setting as well.

Finally, I copy paste some information from the note 3364010 for Public Cloud WM, and I think it may helpful to you.

6. Scan GS1 barcodes using an RF device in Warehouse Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

The GS1-128 standard, indicated by the symbology identifier “]C1”, and the GS1 QR code, indicated by “]Q3”, are both supported. Other barcodes with different symbology identifiers are not supported so they must not be passed as input to the RFUI framework. RF devices must be configured so that they can convert the AI delimiter characters (also known as Group Separators, <GS>, or FNC1) to “]C1” during the scanning of GS1 labels.

Refer to the following pages about configuring RF devices (Zebra as an example) for the conversion:

Search and Replace Group Separator

DataWedge for Android: Search and Remove Group Separator

Removing or Replacing a Barcode Character(s) Using ADF (Advanced Data Formatting) and 123Scan

Quantity field validation via GS1 barcode scanning is not supported in the picking process because it may cause quantity difference during picking. You must enter the quantity manually.

If you scan a GTIN, it won't be converted to the SAP standard product number on the RF UI.

For flexible-length fields that are not placed at the end of a GS1 barcode, you need to use the AI delimiter characters to end of the fields. For example, if you have a product (ID: TG21) with a flexible-length field (batch number: 001), the barcode should be “]C110001]C1240TG21”.

For fixed-length fields, you must not use the AI delimiter characters to the end of the fields. For example, if you have a fixed-length field (best before date: 2025.03.27) for your product (ID: TG11), the barcode should be “]C115250327240TG11”.

Note that in Warehouse Management in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, product ID is the additional product identification in GS1.

You can check the configuration in the Implementation Activities app (Logistics, Transportation, and Warehousing>Warehouse Management>Mobile Data Entry>Mobile RF Devices in Warehouse Processes>Maintain Bar Code Specification).

 

Karl

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud for adv. variant config - professional
entry.content:
Hello @SKAE.

Thank you for your feedback and follow up,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, there is no role called Advanced Variant Configuration. Instead, AVC functions are delivered through standard roles catalogues such as:

  • SAP_BR_PRODUCT_CONFIG_MODELER – for dependency modelling and configuration profiles
  • SAP_BR_PRODUCT_CONFIGURATOR – for using configuration in sales/production

These roles only become visible once scope item 6GU – Advanced Variant Configuration is activated in your tenant. In IAM Information System, try searching for “Product Config” or “Configuration” rather than AVC.

Useful SAP References.

  • SAP Help-Using Contract Management with Advanced Variant Configuration 
  • SAP-Help Business Role Templates 

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: RF Multi HU Picking
entry.content:
Hello @Eric_SAUTOT64 

To achieve the HU → destination → next HU behaviour, use one of these that work in Public Cloud.

A) No configuration: pick by Warehouse Task (single-HU)

Use the RF menu option that picks by WT / single HU instead of Multi-HU by WO. It will prompt for the destination after each HU.

B) With config: make 1 HU per Warehouse Order (WOCR split)

Keep the WO-based UI but force one HU per WO so the standard flow naturally becomes HU → destination

Step-by-step (WOCR):

Find the current rule: Check WOCR Determination for your Warehouse Number, Process Type, and Activity Area used for picking.

Create a Z rule such as Z_HU1 in Define Creation Rules for Warehouse Orders:

  • HU-oriented = ON
  • Max HUs per WO = 1
  • Turn off grouping that pulls multiple HUs together (e.g., group by destination, consolidation flags).
  • Leave generous limits for WTs/items/weight so those don’t force grouping.

Determination: Put Z_HU1 first for your picking Process Type(s) so it’s selected.

Test: Release picking for 3 HUs → you should get 3 WOs 1 HU each. In RF “Picking by WO”, you’ll now confirm HU → destination per WO.

If it still groups HUs:

  • Check WT attributes, no consolidation group forcing merge.
  • Ensure there’s no destination-based grouping left on the rule.
  • Verify you’re using the intended Process Type in the determination.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Before / After – SAP UI Redesign
entry.content:
When I looked at the old screen, the main issues I noticed were not only visual but structural:
•Poor hierarchy → information was presented at the same level, which made it harder for the user to know where to focus first.
•User distraction → too many elements with equal weight distracted the employee from the main task.
•Navigation challenges → actions were not clearly grouped, so the workflow felt fragmented.
•Overloaded tables → data was shown without enough spacing or prioritization, creating cognitive load.

For ERP systems like SAP, the priority is not just to make the interface “look good.” The real challenge is User Experience (UX):
•Helping users perform complex tasks efficiently.
•Reducing errors and time spent on repetitive actions.
•Making the workflow intuitive even with heavy data and multiple modules.

That’s why in this redesign, my focus was on clarity, task hierarchy, and reducing friction. The UI itself is simple, but the main value comes from a UX approach that improves how people interact with the system daily.

The next iterations will be aligned with the SAP Fiori guidelines, combining both usability and a consistent visual design.

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud Edition Revaluation Order Maintenance
entry.content:
Hello @ConsultorSAPFICOLimaPeru 

Good question,

As of today, the revaluation of maintenance orders at actual activity prices using the tcodes KON2/CON2/MFN2 logic. is not available in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

There’s no equivalent Public-Cloud app ID for it. SAP Support Portal-2959209 - Order Revaluation (CON2) is not available in Public Cloud

What you do have in Public Cloud is Actual Costing (scope item 33Q) and Actual Price Calculation for activity types; these handle inventory/WIP/COGS and activity price determination, but not the order-level revaluation step you know from ECC/on-prem. SAP Community-Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP

For Public Cloud EAM, you can monitor costs with apps like Maintenance Order Costs (F4603) and proceed with standard settlement, but you cannot revalue the maintenance order itself at actual rates. fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: SAP to Non-SAP Using ODATA Service
entry.content:
@janardhan-16 

Update: I'm sorry, please disregard the following as it's the method for CAP.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The following section of capire document provides a common approach for calling external services.

https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/guides/using-services

The steps listed below are the basic settings:

  1. Import the service metadata via the `cds import <input_file> --as cds ` command.
  2. Define an entity using the imported entity definition, or consume the remote service in the event handler.
  3. Bind the destination and connectivity (in case of on-premise destinations)  services.

If you are using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), you can import service definitions from the service center which performs step 1 and creates necessary configurations.

entry.title: Re: Actual cost rate calculation - cost centers (KSII) un...
entry.content:
Hello @mostafa_mahmoud1811_598 

You're very close. The result “200 EGP/hr for both activities” shows that the system didn’t include your two assignments in the splitting structure during KSII execution. When a cost line isn't assigned to any specific task, the remaining costs are allocated across all activities based on their actual quantities. Given your numbers (900 + 500 = 1,400 units and 3 h + 4 h = 7 hours), this results in 1,400 divided by 7, which equals 200 for both TESTL2 and TESTM2.

Here’s how to achieve the result you expect (L2 = 900/3 = 300; M2 = 500/4 = 125):

What to Verify/Fix

Cost element groups really encompass the posted G/Ls.

  • YBMF_P05 must contain 61100000 (Payroll).
  • YBMF_P04 must contain 63001000 (Electricity/Utilities).
    (Your description had these swapped once—double-check in Edit Cost Element Groups.)

Activity type hierarchy groups include only the specified activity.

  • In YBGH_P00, put TESTL2 under YBGHP5 and TESTM2 under YBGHP4.
  • Make sure those nodes don’t also include other activity types for this test.

Splitting structure (A000 → YA) assignments are active and point group→group
In Define Splitting Structure (structure YA, rule YA1 – Activity Quantity Actual):

  • Assignment YA5: Cost Element Group = YBMF_P05 → Activity Type Group = YBGHP5
  • Assignment YA4: Cost Element Group = YBMF_P04 → Activity Type Group = YBGHP4
  • Save/transport and ensure this structure is the one used in Controlling Area A000.

Run KSII with “Detail Lists” (important)

  • In Execute Actual Price Calculation, tick Detail Lists and Test Run first.
  • In the log, open “Splitting: Assignments” and verify:
      • 61100000 flows to YA5 → YBGHP5 → TESTL2 (900)
      • 63001000 flows to YA4 → YBGHP4 → TESTM2 (500)
        If those amounts show under “Remainder/Not Assigned”, one of the mappings above didn’t catch the line (fix 1–3).

Ignore credits when reading the log
Your cost center already has credits from activity confirmations (-510 and -400). KSII continues to calculate actual prices based on debits per assignment divided by the actual quantity. With proper mapping, you’ll see approximately 300 for TESTL2 and 125 for TESTM2. The difference compared to the credits at plan (170/100) appears as under- or over-absorption. Note that revaluation of receivers isn’t available in Public Cloud for PP orders; however, the actual price will be correctly set at the end of the period.

  • Expected calculations with your data:
  • TESTL2: 900 EGP debits / 3 h = 300 Egp/h
  • TESTM2: 500 EGP debits / 4 h = 125 Egp/hh

Let me know if it helps

With kind regards

Chuma

GenAI asist content( Useful SAP References documentation)

Configuration for Actual Cost Rate Calculation-SAP Help

3007128 - How to exclude costs from App Actual Cost Rate Calculation - Cost Centers

Manage Global Hierarchies-SAP Help

entry.title: Re: OD Sldreg connectfile Automatic

Dear Customer, 

The SAP_BCControlInstance is registered through the sapstartsrv process and not via the Outside Discovery. For further details, you can refer to the documentation provided in 1717846 - sapstartsrv SLD registration.

entry.title: Re: #CoE#MRAS Is there any official Coding Guidelines for New Custom Development Requests?
entry.content: The short answer is yes, there are extensive and official coding guidelines and frameworks mandated by SAP to ensure your custom developments adhere to the Clean Core strategy. The "Clean Core" is not just a recommendation; it's a fundamental principle for SAP S/4HANA Cloud. The goal is to keep the core system pristine, avoiding modifications or custom code that would complicate future upgrades. All custom logic must be built outside or on top of the core in a sustainable way

entry.title: Re: SDA Connectivity with MSSQL - Authentication Options
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Thank you for contacting SAP Support.

Regarding to your concern, would you please refer to KBA 2998731 - SDA connection via TSL/SSL ? 
It says that "Please note: A SSL capability for a non HANA ODBC remote source is not implemented. If this is needed for you, please open a feature request like described in the SAP Note 2265872 - Feature requests for the SAP HANA Platform".

In addition, SSO(Single Sign-On) with Kerberos is also applicable to the scenario where the target remote source is also HANA database.
Regarding to this, you can refer to 'Managing Single Sign-On (SSO) with Kerberos'. 
"SAP HANA smart data access supports single sign-on with Kerberos for connections to SAP HANA on-premise remote sources."

So, I believe you may need to find a way of implementing your requirement with the help of MSSQL admin or supporting team, for example using the mapping between the Active Directory(AD) and MSSQL server.
Since I'm not the expert on AD and MSSQL server, please consult them if it's possible.

For your information, please refer to MS document below.
DSN and Connection String Keywords and Attributes

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: How to Define Posting Rules-Period Selection field？
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Period Selection = YTD does not override posting period. It only changes how balances are accumulated (year-to-date basis). Actual posting period is always controlled by Posting Date and Fiscal Year Variant.

entry.title: Re: How to get the Agent ID which is used for CA Introscope
entry.content:
Dear customer,

To find the corresponding Agent ID:

  1. Go to Agent Administration and search for the agents using the host names where Introscope system is installing at.

  2. Select the host entry and click "Open Agent Internal".

  3. In the Agent tab, you will see the Host ID. This Host ID is also the Agent ID, which can be used to delete the entry from table DPC_AGENT_REG.

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: ABAP + MCP: Precise Answers from ABAP Keyword Documentation and other Best Practice Sources
entry.content:
This is a follow-up to my post about the SAP Documentation MCP Server. Since then, I have added a big ABAP-focused update and a practical guideline for formatting SAP Community posts. The goal stays the same: give you fast, grounded answers in your AI tools and make publishing smoother and predictable.

ABAP-first: What’s new in the SAP Docs MCP server

GitHub Repository: https://github.com/marianfoo/mcp-sap-docs 

The server now bundles the official ABAP Keyword Documentation as files, the SAP Clean ABAP style guide and the DSAG ABAP Leitfaden for clean-core development, plus real showcase projects such as the ABAP Platform Fiori Feature Showcase (RAP/OData V4) and the CAP Fiori Elements showcase. ABAP search is fully integrated into the standard sap_docs_search interface (same as UI5, CAP, and wdi5) with intelligent version handling: latest by default, or targeted when you include versions like 7.57 in your query. Results are curated for quality with rich snippets and official source links.

Try it quickly

Hosted endpoints: SSE and Streamable HTTP. Full background and client setup are in my original article: Feed SAP Help, UI5 APIs & SAP Community Content into your AI with this Open Source MCP Server. For Eclipse specifics and Copilot notes, see the README section: Eclipse + GitHub Copilot. Unfortunately GitHub Copilot is not yet supported in Agent Mode with MCP Server (see GitHub Issue)

ABAP dev setup: VS Code

The official path is Eclipse with ABAP Development Tools (ADT). As this is not yet supported let´s do this in VS Code.

Start with ABAP remote filesystem (abapfs) to connect VS Code directly to your ABAP system and work on server objects. It’s less capable than ADT but very responsive and includes neat extras like listing changed sources by transport, normalizing diffs, where‑used, transport handling, short‑dump views, integrated abapGit/test explorer, and even a debugger. Pair it with abaplint for VS Code for syntax highlighting and static checks. If you work heavily with annotations, install an ABAP CDS language support extension as well (for example, ABAP CDS Language Support).

A minimal quick start with abapfs looks like this:

# 1) Ensure ADT ICF is active (SICF: /sap/bc/adt)
# 2) In VS Code install "ABAP remote filesystem" and run:
#    Command Palette -> "ABAPfs: Create connection" then "ABAPfs: Connect to an ABAP system"
# 3) Use the ABAPfs explorer to open packages, create objects, and activate

Once you have set it up, you can use the data with any model and the MCP server and edit ABAP and RAP models.

Search ABAP (one standard tool)

All ABAP queries use sap_docs_search. General questions return the latest ABAP content plus related sources; adding a version like 7.57 narrows results to that specific version.

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_search",
  "query": "inline declarations"
}

Version-targeted:

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_search",
  "query": "LOOP 7.57"
}

Retrieve a specific document with the standard getter:

{
  "tool": "sap_docs_get",
  "library_id": "/abap-docs-latest/abeninline_declarations"
}

Claude.ai

Of course, this works in any LLM client such as Claude. ABAP is available through the same standard interface (sap_docs_search / sap_docs_get) — no special tools required. If you already added the remote server, nothing else is needed.
See the conversation here: https://claude.ai/share/6ec2a83a-da6e-4505-9af8-73d72f64adad 

Wrap-up

The ABAP additions to the MCP server make answers fast and precise by serving small, source‑attributed documents first. Search is unified via sap_docs_search with intelligent version handling (latest by default, targeted when specified), and results are curated with rich snippets and official links. Use ADT for the fully supported experience, or VS Code with abapfs + abaplint (+ CDS support) when you prefer a lightweight editor. And when you publish, stick to the allowed HTML subset for clean rendering.

entry.title: Re: SDA Connectivity with MSSQL - Authentication Options
entry.content:
Hi,

Starting from Microsoft ODBC Driver 18, the encrypt connection property is enabled by default and supports SSL connections.
This means that TLS encryption is also enabled for connections to older versions of Microsoft SQL Server databases that use Microsoft ODBC Driver 18 with the default setting.
Additionally, 'Managing Single Sign-On (SSO) with Kerberos' is only applicable when the remote source is SAP HANA 2.0 Platform Edition (on-premise). This is not supported when the remote source is Microsoft SQL Server.
In that sense, please adapt the answer accordingly.

Best,
Seungjoon

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in August
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in August

Another month with two nice new release deliveries ✨

Learn more in my short top features video in August 2025 on YouTube 📺

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in August

 

Transformation Flow: Processing in Batches

You can now break down large transformation flow datasets into batches to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) errors when using the SAP HANA runtime in Datasphere. Defining batches on transformation flows enhances the performance and reliability, while ensuring efficient data integration and processing.

You find this feature in the data integration monitor as it is part of the runtime settings under the Batches tab. Simply pick a suitable column and define the batch sizes in number or records. You can also define to use it only for a large initial load or both initial and delta loads.

➡️  More information.

 

New source and targets for Replication Flows

Microsoft OneLake as a Source for Your Replication Flow

You can now use Microsoft OneLake—which was formerly also known as Azure Data Lake Generation 2—, and the corresponding connection type to add sources to replication flows and replicate data in CSV format from the source for initial loads.

➡️  More information.

  • Cloud Storage Provider Sources
  • Microsoft OneLake Connections

 

SAP Signavio as Target for Your Replication Flows

You can now use connection type SAP Signavio and replication flows to load data from SAP source systems, such as SAP S/4HANA and others, into SAP Signavio as target system. This allows an efficient and scalable data replication into the SAP Signavio solution.

➡️  More information.

  • SAP Signavio Targets
  • SAP Signavio Connections

 

SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel

There is a very nice feature new in SAP Analytics Cloud, which I think is super useful for many of you. With the QRC 3 release, you can transfer a table from an SAC story to Excel and further use it with the add-in. In Excel, the transferred table is based on the same data source, for example Datasphere, and has the same navigation state (dimensions, measures in rows and columns, filters, and variables). The idea is to benefit from native Excel capabilities on Datasphere data in real time. You can adjust the report, add custom functions on top of the table, and more.

➡️  More information.

 



SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

 

Starting September 10, the Getting Started Series kicks off with three modules

  • Module 1: Build an Intelligent Application Grounded in Data Products (Sep 10, 2025)
  • Module 2: Fuel AI Innovation with SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud (Sep 24, 2025)
  • Module 3: Create and Enrich an Analytical Model with SAP Datasphere (Oct 8, 2025)

👉  Sign up today on the registration page.

➡️  Step-By-Step Guide: Getting started with the SAP Business Data Cloud Basic Trial

 

Learning Update

Our learning colleagues are currently defining a brand new course: Becoming an SAP Data Architect.

You will learn:

🔹How Data Architecture enables efficiency, innovation, and measurable business outcomes

🔹 Ways to communicate complex data concepts clearly — to both technical and non-technical stakeholders

🔹 How to identify and prioritize opportunities, build business cases, and articulate value

🔹 Techniques for designing target-state architectures aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere

🔹 Storytelling methods to overcome resistance and foster adoption of data-driven change

 

This course is the first step in a learning path:

✅  Start with the free “Becoming an SAP Data Architect” course in November 2025

✅  Continue with a free advanced course coming early 2026

🏆  Together, they prepare you for a brand-new SAP Data Architect certification in 2026

 

My favorite blogs in August

 

Use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Estimator

There is a great blog series about the capacity estimator SAP Business Data Cloud, which of course also includes the SAP Datasphere estimator by @FernandaFroelich. Not all blogs are published yet as the series is work in progress, but already a great start:

  1. Learn How to use SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator?
  2. Explore How to edit a quota assignment in SAP Business Data Cloud?
  3. Use the Capacity Unit Estimator across SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud rewiring of existing Datasphere and SAC tenants

My dear colleague @Ammar_Naji has updated his blog on the rewiring option for existing SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud tenants. Very informative and includes all the steps which need to be done.

➡️  UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

 

Open Resource Directory

This is a must read for all SAP Business Data Cloud experts out there:
➡️  Why we created Open Resource Discovery

The Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is the core protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery within SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog written by @SimonHeimler explains the concepts behind the scenes and gives you links to resources where you find further details.

 

SAP Datasphere SQL Navigator browser plugin

SAP Mentor and active community member @kostertim has created a very useful browser plugin to be able to navigate from one SQL view to another by just highlighting the view and using a hotkey combination or browser context menu—avoiding a lot of copy-and-paste efforts. All is described in his blog ➡️  DSP SQL Navigator – Stop copy pasting URLs! And of course the YouTube video:

entry.title: Installation, Migration , Uninstallation Of MAXDB 7.9 and content Server 7.5
entry.content:
Introduction :

Blog provides step by step procedure to perform migration of SAP MaxDB Content Server 6.4 from windows server 2003 to SAP MaxDB Content Server 7.5 Windows server 2022 using online backup/restore method by creating a standby database. It is focusing on a method to reduce downtime during MaxDB Content Server migration of large database. This is needed for systems which are highly critical to get downtime for migration purpose from customer.

SUMMARY : 

This blog outlines a step-by-step process to migrate SAP MaxDB Content Server from version 6.4 on Windows Server 2003 to version 7.5 on Windows Server 2022 using the online backup/restore method. The approach involves creating a standby database to minimize downtime, making it ideal for critical systems where extended downtime is not feasible.

System Overview:


Source System:

  • MaxDB version: 7.6.11
  • Content Server 6.4

 

  • Server: Windows Server 2003.



Target system:

  • MaxDB version : 7.9.10.5
  • Content Server 7.5

 

  • Server: Windows Server 2022



Migration Method: Online Backup/Restore

Backup Tool: Database Studio

DB Size: 250 GB

 

 

 

Preparation:

 

  1. Install Content Server 7.5 on the target server

  2. Install MAXDB 7.9.10.5 on the target Server

     

    Installation of Content Server 7.5

    Perform the installation of SAP Content Server 7.5 instance on target server (Windows Server 2023) using SWPM.

    Overview :

    1. Content Server 7.5 is a standalone application which can use MAXDB as a storage and Filesystem as a storage. As of content Server 6.5 , you can install content Server 6.5 and MAXDB 7.9 in one step but in Content Server 7.5 , you need to install Content Server 7.5 and MAXDB 7.9 as a different instance. You have to  install Content Server 7.5 and then MAXDB 7.9.

    2. Content Server 6.5 doesn't have any SID while content Server 7.5 is having SID which makes it easy to integrate the system for monitoring purpose. 

    3. Content Server 6.5 is compatible in windows 2019 as per PAM while content Server 7.5 is compatible for all windows server as well as all NetWeaver version whether it is NetWeaver 7.0.

    4. Content Server 6.5 needs IIS configuration while its not required in installation of content Server 7.5

     

     


     

    Perform the installation of Content Server 7.5 instance on target server (Windows Server 2022) using SWPM 1.0 latest SP.

     

    changed sapcs to /ContentServer/ContentServer.dll and configure HTTP port to 1290

     

    Perform the installation of MAXDB 7.9 instance on target server (Windows Server 2022) using SWPM 1.0 latest SP

     

  3. In Unix it will ask for SAR file 

 

  1. Cutover Plan for the Migration from MAXDB 7.6 to MAXDB 7.9

     

    Master Note : 2786364 - SAP Content Server and Cache Server 7.5 (and higher) 

    Now the question comes in mind if we can use the backup restore method to migrate the MAXDB 7.6 to MAXDB 7.9. The answer is yes but source and target system should be unicode.

     

    1. Stop the SAP application so that no one can upload the documents on the content Server

     

    2. Take complete backup from old MAXDB 7.6 and move the backup to new server.

    3. Recover the database in MAXDB 7.9

     

    4. Now change the password of SUPERDBA user to the same password which you used during installation as new password came from the source system and run the load_systab

     

    Check in content server URL is working or giving the error. Below error will solve once you change the password for SUPERDBA user.

     

    Make change in OAC0.

     

    Go to OAC0 , Now give HTTP server to target server
    Give HTTP port 1290 difined during installation
    Ensure firwall is enabled between SAP Application Server and Target Content Server
    Click on Exchange certificate and do the connection test
    Now go to csadmin . It will promt for password you need to give password of content server sidadm and password
    Certificate : Send the certificate and activate it
    Setting :
    ContentStorageHost : target host
    StorageDrive : SAPDBStorage
    Security : 1
    ContentStorageName : CPX
    ContentStorageDriver : SAP MAXDB CPX(Unicode)

    Save it

     

    You may encounter the error 

    To fix the issue follow : 2141940 - Database Repositories adjustment when upgrading to SAP Content Server 6.4. Note contains one script cs650prep.sql which will fix issue from migrating date from content Server 6.5 to 7.5 . You need to run the script in target MAXDB 7.9 database studio or command prompt.

     

    After that this issue will be fixed.

     

    Now verify the availability of the new Content Server

    You can run reports RSCMSTH0, RSCMSTH1 and RSCMSTH2 to check the new installation. Additionally, functional tests should be performed to verify that repositories and documents can be accessed normally.

     

    Now you can handover the system to customer after shutdown the old content Server for testing.

     

     

    Uninstalling the old Content Server and MAXDB Instance

    You can uninstall using SWPM but sometimes you can encounter the error for which you need to delete the windows registry entry and also uninstall packages from control panel -> uninstall program

     

    Control Panel -> uninstall program

     

    SUMMARY

    This blog outlines a step-by-step process to migrate SAP MaxDB Content Server from version 6.4 on Windows Server 2003 to version 7.5 on Windows Server 2022 using the online backup/restore method. The approach involves creating a standby database to minimize downtime, making it ideal for critical systems where extended downtime is not feasible.

    Thanks for reading my post.

entry.title: Re: gCTS - Backup and Restore specific ABAP Object - Git
entry.content:
Hi,
gCTS does not offer any kind of cherry picking. You can activate any commit in the list of commits and therewith any software state that you had in the past. Details are described in here https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/4a368c163b08418890a406d413933ba7/2af3e9477392441e80651339352acdc1.html 
Allowing the restore of single objects could cause many issues as you cannot recover a single object - many objects in a git repository might have dependencies and just activating one of them could result in a not working application. We therefore only allow activating software states represented by a certain commit.

Kind regards
Karin

entry.title: Migration SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration using Pipeline concepts
entry.content:
Dear SAP consultants:

I have been working on migrating from SAP PI/PO to SAP Cloud Integration, and I would like to share my experience with the Pipeline concept introduced by SAP for migration projects. Since there are not many blogs or discussions on this topic, I thought it would be helpful to share my experience.

Let’s quickly recap SAP PI/PO. In PI/PO, we usually create common IDOC and proxy channels to connect SAP ERP with the PI/PO system for both outbound and inbound communication. A single IDOC & Proxy channel can be reused across multiple flows/scenarios. If needed, we can also create multiple IDOC channels using the same destination in SM59. However, this approach doesn’t work the same way in SAP Cloud Integration. One HTTP destination can’t be used for multiple flow.

Example: if there are 100 IDOC flows from SAP ERP to SAP Cloud Integration, we need to create 100 separate HTTP destinations - each one mapped to its corresponding iFlow endpoint. Unlike PI/PO, where a single destination could be reused, SAP CI requires a unique destination per flow.

I believe this was the initial perspective of most SAP PI/PO consultants, but with SAP’s continuous support, better approaches are being discovered day by day.
Since we all started the migration journey some time ago, there are many ways to handle the IDOC and proxy scenarios.
However, one of the best ways to use the Pipeline concept for Asynchronous Pattern.

I will try to explain in simple terms.

  1. We require to use the Standard Pipeline Template provided by SAP.

  2. JMS queues  for retry mechanism. 
  3. Partner Directory setup  for each IDOC/proxy flow.

Let’s discuss end to end Outbound IDOC scenario to understand more.

1. We require to use the Standard Pipeline Template provided by SAP: 

Copy the Standard Package  “Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates“


Deploy the below highlighted iFlows.

Pipeline Generic - Script Collection: Deploy the common scripts collection package will be used across the pipeline steps.

Step 01: Pipeline Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
Deploy and use end point of this iFlow in HTTP destination created in SAP system.
So, the connection established and when IDOC triggered – it will point to this flow.
Basically, this flow will receive the IDOC from SAPERP and send to JMS Queue PIPQ01. 

Step 02: Pipeline Generic Step02 - Inbound Processing
The flow will pick the messages from first JMS queue PIPQ01 and run through flow by determining the partner ID which is created in Partner directory. (will discuss this part below) then will drop to JMS queue PIPQ02.
If any issue occurs during this flow, it will be go back to PIPQ01_DLQ(first flow dead letter queue) after max retries.

Step 03: Pipeline Generic Step04 - Receiver Determination
This step to find the receiver using XSLT mapping maintained in Partner directory. We will have to prepare the XSLT mapping and define the condition, upload it partner directory.
The flow will pick the messages from second JMS queue PIPQ02 and run through the iFlow to check the receiver --> then drop the message to JMS queue PIPQ03.
If any issue occurs, receiver determination step failed them it will be moved to last step dead letter queue after retries i.e PIPQ02_DLQ.

Step 04: Pipeline Generic Step05 - Interface Determination
Again in the same way, the Integration flow will pick the messages from third JMS queue PIPQ03 and find interface mapping path and drop the messages to last fourth queue PIPQ04.
If this iFlow fails with issue then message moved back to last step Dead letter queue i.e PIPQ03_DLQ

Step 05: Pipeline Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing
Outbound processing step will pick the message from JMS queue PIPQ04 and identify the next iFlow. (based on process direct adapter path) and send messages to corresponding iFlow.
If this iFlow fails with issue then message moved back to last step Dead letter queue i.e PIPQ04_DLQ

Step 06: (scenario specific flow- you can use custom names)
In this flow Mapping conversion and connection to receiver. We have SAP provided templates as well for this step, however I haven’t used them. Created own custom Integration flow to handle the mapping and connection to receiver.
If any issue occurs the message will be failed status and message processing is then retried from the last integration flow.

  • We can migrate/import mapping from SAP PO ESR to custom last step iFlow. 
  • The process direct adapter channel path should match the one defined in the interface determination mapping.

 

Below table summarizes  all pipeline steps and how the integration flow works: 

 

2. JMS queues required for retry mechanism:

Required total 8 JMS queues. 4 normal queues and 4 dead letter queues to handle the retry mechanism.

(PIPQ01, PIPQ01_DLQ, PIPQ02, PIPQ02_DLQ, PIPQ03, PIPQ03_DLQ, PIPQ04, PIPQ04_DLQ)

Once we deploy the above standard SAP iFlows - the below JMS queues will automatically created.

3. Partner Directory:

Create the PID for each interface.
PID is combination of sender system and sender interface name
Example: SAPCLNT100~ORDERS.ORDERS05
               <sendersystem>~<senderInterfacename>



Entity Type: String Parameter: we use this parameter to maintain the JMS retries count.
ID: MaxJMSRetries
Value: 3 or 4, If message fails in any pipeline step based on this value, it retries count intervals.

Binary Parameter: we use this parameter to upload the xsl mapping code for receiver and interface determination.
ID = receiverDetermination
ID = interfaceDetermination_<ReceiverName>
Create the XSLT mapping for both receiver determination and interface determination and upload.

Whatever the receivername you maintained in the receiver determination, will be automatically taken that name in interfaceDetermination_"Receivername" – so use the same name in ID. Else it will be failed with error.

Sample XSLT code for receiver determination:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="3.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
    <xsl:template match="/">
        <ns0:Receivers xmlns:ns0="http://sap.com/xi/XI/System">
            <xsl:choose>
                <xsl:when test="/ORDERS05/IDOC/EDI_DC40/RCVPRN = 'Germany'">
                    <Receiver>
                        <Service>GermanyBMW</Service>
                    </Receiver>
                </xsl:when>
                <xsl:otherwise>
                    <Receiver>
                        <Service>NotDefined</Service>
                    </Receiver>
                </xsl:otherwise>
            </xsl:choose>
        </ns0:Receivers>
    </xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>

sample XSLT code for interface determination:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<xsl:stylesheet version="3.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform">
  <xsl:template match="/">
    <ns0:Interfaces xmlns:ns0="http://sap.com/xi/XI/System">
      <Interface>
        <Index>1</Index>
        <Service>Integration_Mapping_Step_and_Connection_to_Receiver_Step07</Service>
      </Interface>
    </ns0:Interfaces>
  </xsl:template>
</xsl:stylesheet>


Alternative Partners
Agency: SenderSystem Name (SAPERP)
Scheme: SenderInterface
ID: SenderInterfaceName

The same way we can add more entries in partner directory for different interfaces.

ex: SAPCLNT100~SHPMNT.SHPMNT06
       SAPCLNT100~CustomerData_Out
       etc...

Testing:

We are ready to test now. Let's do it.

I have triggered test IDOC from ERP and below is the message flow of all pipeline steps handled.

I hope this provides useful insights into migration from SAP PI/PO to Cloud Integration for handling IDOC asynchronous scenarios.

Advantages:

  • Design: Pipeline steps break down integration flow into clear, manageable steps (ex: sender, processing, receiver). This makes it easier to design, debug, and maintain integration scenarios.
  • Re-try mechanisms. Since all pipeline steps decoupled, JMS queues handle the automatic retry to process if the messages fail.
  • Monitoring: Each pipeline step can be monitored individually, helping identify bottlenecks or failures quickly.
  • Easy Migration: We  just needed to import the mapping from SAP PO - everything else is already available in the pipeline template to complete the integration.

Reference: Fully Decoupled Pipeline 

 

Regards,
Sathish Kumar B P 
SAP Integration Developer

entry.title: Re: Deleting rows based on other rows - Data Action
entry.content:
@andreag412 For Option 1 , I think you want to delete the data where currency is not the same as Local currency of the market. In your sample data its CNY for Market CN. If your market dimension has an attribute for currency with value CN, the below sample Data Action logic can work. For both Option 1 and 2 Assumption is Currency attribute in MARK is set to CNY

MEMBERSET [d/DATASOURCE]="ADD"
IF [d/MARK].[p/Currency] != [d/CC].[p/id] THEN
  DELETE()
ENDIF

For Option 2 

MEMBERSET [d/DATASOURCE]="INP"
MEMBERSET [d/CC]="#"

DATA([d/CC]=[d/MARK].[p/Currency])=RSEULTLOOKUP([d/CC]="#")

 

Hope this helps !!

Nikhil

You cannot use Data Action to write data (master data) to dimensions. You can only use it to write/update fact data in model. The only option I see is using Javascript to handle this. It would be much easier if you provide an example of what you intend to do.

entry.title: Re: MIGO Error
entry.content:
Check the following:-

  • In PO History tab, check whether the entire quantity has already been inwarded
  • If the item is set Deletion indicator in PO, it wont appear in MIGO

entry.title: Re: Extra line items with zero value in settlement document
entry.content:
Hello,

The cause of this could be due to incorrect configuration of the split criteria for settlement in the profile for business volume determination for the condition contract. The system tries to match up accruals from WCOCOF with settlement line items. This is where the configuration in field "Field name accruals reversal split" becomes important. You can try to debug method GET_ACCRUALS (CL_WB2_REBATE_SETTLEMENT) to see why these incorrect lines get added to the settlement document.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Need API to Trigger Outbound Payment Status After Ban...
entry.content:
Hi Mahavir

Based on the details provided, you are describing a classic integration after bank statement posting use case. Let’s break it down and give you a Public Cloud aligned answer.

The following are the key Points from your described scenario

  • Inbound: Invoices are posted from a third-party system into S/4HC.
  • Payment: Process runs in S/4HC, reconciliation is done with BANK_STATEMENT_POST_IN.
  • Requirement: As soon as invoices are cleared by the bank statement, push the Paid or Cleared status goes back to the third-party system automatically.
  1. Here are some business events in public cloud

SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides business events that can be consumed in SAP Event Mesh or via SAP Integration Suite.

For your particular case:

  • When bank statements are posted, the actual FI clearing happens through Accounting Document clearing.
  • Moving forward you should look at the Journal Entry Cleared (JournalEntry.Cleared) and the Supplier Invoice Cleared (SupplierInvoice.Cleared) due to their relevance to your scenario. These are published as Enterprise Events in S/4HC → BTP Event Mesh → can trigger your outbound interface.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Events

  1. APIs to Read Status
  • You are correct, BusinessPartnerPaymentStatus API allows you to query open/cleared items.
  • Alternatively, Journal Entry Read or Supplier Invoice API can also provide cleared status. But APIs are pull-based and you will have to schedule jobs to fetch cleared items.
  1. The recommended extension strategy is to combine Business Events with APIs: Subscribe to SupplierInvoice.Cleared or JournalEntry.Cleared event, trigger your iFlow or CAP app when the event is raised, use the API to enrich details such as invoice number, amount and status. Finally push the status to your third-party system. This ensures event-driven push without custom BAdIs in core.
  2. If No Suitable Event exists, sometimes, bank statement specific events are not directly published.
  • If that is the case then:
    • Use Custom CDS View plus Custom Business Object to collect cleared items after BANK_STATEMENT_POST_IN.
    • Expose it as a custom outbound API and schedule it via Communication Arrangement
  • Please note that the preferred option is Enterprise Events, as this is SAP’s clean-core strategy in Public Cloud.

I hope this provides the desired result. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: TO CARRYFORWARD SPECIFIC MEASURES TO THE NEW APPROVAL YEAR
entry.content:
Business Scenario:

  • A new approval year (2025) was created by copying the 2024 Investment Program.
  • A new project/WBS was created and assigned to the 2024 IM Program.
  • The business now wants to include only specific WBS elements in the 2025 IM Program.

 

Steps to Carry Forward Specific WBS:

  1. Transaction Code: IM27_REPEAT
  2. Input:
    • Investment Program Name
    • Source Approval Year: 2024
    • Target Approval Year: 2025 (Auto populate)

3. Command Input: Type =DELTA in the command field.

 

4. Selection Options:

  • Example: D1.11166.1
    • Uncheck all options except WBS Elements (If the budget of the IM node needs to be carried forward, ensure the checkbox for 'Carry forward budget values' is selected).
    • Enter the specific WBS element(s) to be carried forward.

 

5. Execute the Transaction.

6. Verification:

    • Use transaction code IM12 / IM 13 to verify the IM assignments.

Before:

 

After:

 

Outcome:

This process allows you to assign individual measures (WBS elements) to the new IM Program year without affecting the entire structure and based on the requirement ensures that budgets and planned values are carried forward appropriately.

entry.title: The Smart Path to S/4HANA EWM
entry.content:
Overview of the current four solutions

There are currently four SAP solutions to help you manage your warehouse: Stockroom Management; Warehouse Management; EWM Basic; and EWM Advanced. Below, we’ll look at the differences between them. Note that there will be no further development of the first two, as SAP is positioning EWM on S/4HANA as the strategic choice going forward. Its key benefits include:

  • Better warehouse performance
  • Complete process and stock transparency
  • Preconfigured best practice content
  • Clear roadmap of future developments
  • Supported by latest technologies and continuous innovation
  • Scalability and flexible extension options
  • Lowest TCO

Can Stockroom Management replace a transition to EWM?

You probably know that SAP introduced SAP Stockroom Management in 2020, running on S/4HANA. This solution is helpful for small warehouses with predominantly manual processes that only require a few basic functions, such as storage bin management. However, it isn’t suited to industrial companies looking to streamline their logistical processes across the board. For example, Stockroom Management doesn’t include functions such as task and resource management; value-added services; cross-docking; picking waves; or WM-LSR. As noted above, this product will not be developed any further.

Choosing the right EWM solution for you

Now that we’ve established that most companies will likely want to transition to EWM, let’s look at the options available. In terms of the solutions embedded in S/4HANA, you can choose between EWM Basic Warehousing and EWM Advanced Warehousing, for which an additional license is required.  If you prefer a decentralized solution, SAP offers the extended cloud variant of EWM as well as the decentralized version on S/4HANA. It’s important for companies to look into the features and functions they need for their processes and what could be dropped. Here’s an overview to make your selection easier.

 

 

Overview of features and functions in SAP WM offerings

SDT: the optimal migration approach for EWM

Unlike an ECC to S/4HANA transition, migrating to EWM is a little more complex in that the previous system was part of SCM as opposed to ECC. As such, a classic brownfield migration using automatic system conversion isn’t available. One solution would be to start from scratch with a new system (greenfield), although this involves redesigning your processes. Selective data transformation is clearly the better option here, as it enables you to reuse your business and historical data while updating your existing processes. This migration concept is available from SAP as well as its SDT partners: Natuvion, cbs, and SNP.  These offer specialized migration and mapping tools that accelerate the process of data analysis, selection, and verification.

The importance of dealing with transactional data

Customers using EWM 9.x can use the SAP Migration Cockpit to move to S/4HANA, although the cockpit doesn’t handle transactional data, cross-client customizing or user authentication so companies would need to look after those aspects themselves or work with their SAP SDT partner. If they are unable to leave the old transactional data behind, they could use SAP’s SDT partners’ tools to transfer it to the central control system, then to map and update the transactional data prior to migrating it to the new EWM system.

Deciding what to migrate and what to archive

Many companies find the process complex as they often use highly specialized processes, making it difficult to decide what to transfer and what to leave behind. In addition, there may be legal considerations such as a requirement to retain data for a certain number of years. SAP and its SDT partners can assist with this process, particularly with regard to reducing the size of the database to be migrated. S/4HANA databases can be expensive to maintain if they are large and continue to grow. Archiving solutions are available that enable you to keep and access the old data for auditing and research purposes, while only transferring currently useful data. This approach offers big benefits in terms of cost and performance for the new system while preserving and protecting the historical data.

Three key aspects to consider before starting an EWM migration

 

  • The first elementto consider is dealing with the custom code – repository objects – as many warehouses have very specific hardware and structures. The Custom Code Impact Analysis service can help here, as it highlights whether and how this data will be affected by the move to the new infrastructure.
  • The second aspectis closing the old documents. A prerequisite of S/4HANA is that docs are closed before being moved. Yet some documents can’t be closed, especially quality inspection documents and others that have to be open all the time. The SDT approach helps here as it will move both open and closed documents. This applies whether you’re choosing the embedded or the decentralized SAP EWM solution.
  • Last but not least, downtime.Greenfield projects require several shorter downtime incidences, while SDT usually only requires one. Near-zero downtime may not be possible given the specificities of warehouse systems, but the right tools, like those offered by the SAP SDT partners can make a significant contribution to reducing the impact on business continuity.

 

Decentralized option for better performance

SAP and its SDT partners have estimated that 90-95% of their customers decide on a decentralized EWM system on S/4HANA in preference to the embedded variant. This is because it’s the strategic platform and more future-proof from a data volume perspective, especially for customers with large databases and warehouse systems.  In addition, if someone else in your company is doing some heavy-duty data extraction on the ERP system, there may be a slowdown effect on an EWM embedded in the ERP system that would not arise with a decentralized option.

Talk to us!

Despite the complexities of moving from an SCM-based solution to EWM on S/4HANA, SAP and its SDT partners have the tools and experience to smooth the path for its customers. Feel free to contact us to find out more.

For further information you can also have a look into our webinar "SDT - how to deal with other SAP suite solutions? Focus: EWM".
